segments.en: Linked Discourses 22
4. It’s Not Yours
36. A Mendicant (2nd)
At Sāvatthī.

segments.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā … pe … ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

segments.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṃkhittena dhammaṃ desetu yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
segments.en: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
“Mendicant, you’re measured against what you have an underlying tendency for,
and you’re defined by what you’re measured against.
You’re not measured against what you have no underlying tendency for,

segments.pli: yaṃ nānumīyati na tena saṅkhaṃ gacchatī”ti.
segments.en: and you’re not defined by what you’re not measured against.”
“Understood, Blessed One! Understood, Holy One!”

segments.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsī”ti?
segments.en: “But how do you see the detailed meaning of my brief statement?”
“If you have an underlying tendency for form, you’re measured against that,
and you’re defined by what you’re measured against.
If you have an underlying tendency for feeling …
perception …
choices …
consciousness, you’re measured against that,
and you’re defined by what you’re measured against.

segments.pli: Rūpañce, bhante, nānuseti na taṃ anumīyati;
segments.en: If you have no underlying tendency for form, you’re not measured against that,

segments.pli: yaṃ nānumīyati na tena saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: and you’re not defined by what you’re not measured against.
If you have no underlying tendency for feeling …
perception …
choices …
consciousness, you’re not measured against that,

segments.pli: yaṃ nānumīyati na tena saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: and you’re not defined by what you’re not measured against.

segments.pli: Imassa khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
segments.en: That’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”
“Good, good, mendicant!

segments.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsi.
segments.en: It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of what I’ve said in brief like this.
If you have an underlying tendency for form, you’re measured against that,
and you’re defined by what you’re measured against.
If you have an underlying tendency for feeling …
perception …
choices …
consciousness, you’re measured against that,
and you’re defined by what you’re measured against.

segments.pli: Rūpañce, bhikkhu, nānuseti na taṃ anumīyati;
segments.en: If you have no underlying tendency for form, you’re not measured against that,

segments.pli: yaṃ nānumīyati na tena saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: and you’re not defined by what you’re not measured against.
If you have no underlying tendency for feeling …
perception …
choices …
consciousness, you’re not measured against that,

segments.pli: yaṃ nānumīyati na tena saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: and you’re not defined by what you’re not measured against.

segments.pli: Imassa kho, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo”ti … pe …
segments.en: This is how to understand the detailed meaning of what I said in brief.” …

segments.pli: aññataro ca pana so bhikkhu arahataṃ ahosīti.
segments.en: And that mendicant became one of the perfected.

suttaplex.blurb: The Buddha teaches a mendicant who wants to go on retreat that one is measured by what one has an underlying tendency for. The mendicant gives a full explanation.
